thread.title: Teenager rejected from steakhouse job with laughing emoji
thread.title_full: Teenager rejected from steakhouse job with laughing emoji

author: Carri-Ann Taylor and Ben Leo
title: Teenager rejected from steakhouse job with laughing emoji
text:
A TEEN has blasted a restaurant chain for mocking her with a laughing emoji in a text rejecting her for a job. 
Megan Dixon, 18, was sent a message saying “it’s a no” moments after her interview with a Miller and Carter steakhouse in the UK, The Sun reports.
When she asked why she did not get the part-time waitress job, she was sent another poking fun at her use of the word “like” and describing her as “basic”. The text ended with the laugh-cry emoji.
Megan Dixon went for a job as a part-time waitress. Picture: Instagram/@megrdixon Source: Instagram 
Megan Dixon, 18, was rejected by a steakhouse. Picture: Instagram/@megrdixon Source: Instagram 
Ms Dixon said she had been interviewed by the steakhouse branch’s assistant manager Shantel Wesson.
“It was so rude. At the end of the interview, I asked when I would hear back. She told me it was never more than a few days and she had my email. But I got the texts a few seconds after leaving,” she said.
“I was shocked. The least she should have given me was some proper feedback. And the laughing face emoji was so unprofessional. It was a really bitchy thing to do.”
Megan Dixon, 18, tweeted a screenshot of the message and contacted the Miller and Carter Twitter account. Picture: Twitter/@megrdixon Source: Supplied 
She said of the interview: “She didn’t even shake my hand, didn’t have my CV out and was just sat drinking a coffee. Maybe because I’m 18 she thinks it’s OK not to be professional with me? I don’t know.”
Miller and Carter had advertised up to 50 jobs at the new branch in Enderby, Leicestershire, and student Ms Dixon wanted to earn some extra cash for college.
Megan Dixon said she was interviewed by the branch’s assistant manager, Shantel Wesson. Picture: Twitter/@shantel84 Source: Supplied 
Ms Wesson refused to comment but a Miller and Carter spokeswoman said: “We can’t apologise enough to Megan. It was never our intention to be disrespectful or upset her in any way. The texts were sent in error and were intended for our manager, not the candidate.”
She added it was being taken “extremely seriously” and would be investigated.
This story originally appeared in The Sun and has been republished here with permission.
